name: PM - Iterate on Jira Story Given Feedback

parameters.jsonExample:
{
  "Previous Jira Ticket": {
    "Jira Ticket Summary": "TestRail Setup: Configure TestRail as test management tool",
    "Jira Ticket Description": "## User Story

As a quality engineer, I want TestRail configured and integrated with our development workflow, so our team can effectively manage and execute test cases.

## Context

* TestRail is a widely used test case management tool that integrates well with Jira
* We need a centralized place to store and execute test cases
* Previous story WEN-630 called for selecting a test management tool

## Acceptance Criteria

* TestRail instance is set up and accessible to the team
* TestRail is integrated with our Jira instance
* Test case template/structure is defined in TestRail
* Initial test suites are created matching our product structure
* Documentation exists in Dev-Docs on how to:
  * Create test cases
  * Execute test runs
  * View reports
* Team members have appropriate access levels configured
* TestRail API access is configured for potential automation integration

## Resources

* [TestRail Documentation](https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/)
* [TestRail-Jira Integration Guide](https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/integrate/tools/jira/)",
    "Jira Ticket Labels": [
      "Quality_Assurance",
      "Groomed",
      "V0.0.1"
    ],
    "Jira Ticket Fix Version": "V0.0.1",
    "Jira Ticket Epic Id": "WEN-417"
  },
  "Tech Lead Feedback": {
    "Score": 0.7,
    "Feedback": "The ticket WEN-472 'Vendor Script: Implement scheduler config check via API integration' is fairly well structured but has some areas for improvement:

Strengths:
- Clear user story that describes the goal
- Acceptance criteria breaks down the key requirements
- Good technical details around API payloads and error handling
- Includes validation and error handling requirements

Areas for Improvement:
- Could benefit from a 'Context' section explaining the overall workflow and how this fits in
- 'Out of Scope' section would help clarify boundaries
- No mention of non-functional requirements like performance expectations
- Could provide more details on expected error scenarios and how to handle them
- Missing information about test coverage expectations

The ticket seems implementation-ready but would benefit from additional context and clarification of non-functional requirements. Given the complexity of integrating with APIs and handling configurations, a medium-high estimate seems appropriate based on reference tickets.",
    "estimatedTime": 21600
  }
}

parameters.text:
=You are a highly experienced product manager with deep experience in building SaaS products, adhering to Agile best practices, and crafting comprehensive, clear, and highly effective Jira stories for your engineering teams. You are working on creating a new Jira Ticket and have received constructive feedback from your tech lead/principal engineer. Given the previous iteration of the Jira Story, your tech lead's feedback, as well as the Product Overview as well as the team's Current Jira Tickets below, please craft an enhanced Jira ticket in the following format:

---
JSON output format:
{
  "issueType": "<Story, Bug, Task, Epic>",
  "summary": "<Feature Name>: <Concise summary for given the feature prompt>",
  "description": "h2. User Story\n\nAs a <persona type>, I want <something to exist, be done, etc>, so <I or someone related to me can benefit in XYZ way>.\n\nh2. Context\n\n* <Some contextual information 1>\n* <Some contextual information 2>\n* <Some contextual information 3>\n\nh2. Acceptance Criteria\n\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 1 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 2 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 3 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n\nh2. Resources\n\n* <Any relevant resource 1>\n* <Any relevant resource 2>",
  "labels": ["<new or pre-existing label 1 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')", "<new or pre-existing label 2 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')"],
  "fixVersion": "<Either our current fixVersion, 'V0.0.1', or our future next release, 'V0.0.2'>",
  "epicId": "<If a pre-existing suitable epic exists from our pre-existing Jira Stories, then use its id here>",
  "estimatedTime": <The tech lead's estimated amount of time for completing the ticket in seconds, based on the tech lead's understanding of how long previous similar work has taken by looking at other Jira tickets as well as his instinct given his many years of software development>
}
---

## Previous Jira Ticket Iteration:

{{ $('When Executed by Another Workflow').item.json['Previous Jira Ticket'].toJsonString() }}

---

## Tech Lead Feedback:

Score: {{ $('When Executed by Another Workflow').item.json['Tech Lead Feedback'].Score }}

Feedback: {{ $('When Executed by Another Workflow').item.json['Tech Lead Feedback'].Feedback }}

Estimated Time: {{ $('When Executed by Another Workflow').item.json['Tech Lead Feedback'].estimatedTime }} seconds

---

## Product Overview: 

{{ $('Get Project Overview').item.json.content }}

---

## Current Jira Tickets:

{{ $json['Jira Ticket'] }}

parameters.jsonSchemaExample:
{
  "issueType": "<Story, Bug, Task, Epic>",
  "summary": "<Feature Name>: <Concise summary for given the feature prompt>",
  "description": "h2. User Story

As a <persona type>, I want <something to exist, be done, etc>, so <I or someone related to me can benefit in XYZ way>.

h2. Context

* <Some contextual information 1>
* <Some contextual information 2>
* <Some contextual information 3>

h2. Acceptance Criteria

* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 1 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>
* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 2 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>
* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 3 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>

h2. Resources

* <Any relevant resource 1>
* <Any relevant resource 2>",
  "labels": ["<new or pre-existing label 1 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')", "<new or pre-existing label 2 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')"],
  "fixVersion": "<Either our current fixVersion, 'V0.0.1', or our future next release, 'V0.0.2'>",
  "epicId": "<If a pre-existing suitable epic exists from our pre-existing Jira Stories, then use its id here>",
  "estimatedTime": 7200
}

Previous Jira Ticket.Jira Ticket Summary: TestRail Setup: Configure TestRail as test management tool
Previous Jira Ticket.Jira Ticket Description:
## User Story

As a quality engineer, I want TestRail configured and integrated with our development workflow, so our team can effectively manage and execute test cases.

## Context

* TestRail is a widely used test case management tool that integrates well with Jira
* We need a centralized place to store and execute test cases
* Previous story WEN-630 called for selecting a test management tool

## Acceptance Criteria

* TestRail instance is set up and accessible to the team
* TestRail is integrated with our Jira instance
* Test case template/structure is defined in TestRail
* Initial test suites are created matching our product structure
* Documentation exists in Dev-Docs on how to:
  * Create test cases
  * Execute test runs
  * View reports
* Team members have appropriate access levels configured
* TestRail API access is configured for potential automation integration

## Resources

* [TestRail Documentation](https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/)
* [TestRail-Jira Integration Guide](https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/integrate/tools/jira/)

Tech Lead Feedback.Feedback:
The ticket WEN-472 'Vendor Script: Implement scheduler config check via API integration' is fairly well structured but has some areas for improvement:

Strengths:
- Clear user story that describes the goal
- Acceptance criteria breaks down the key requirements
- Good technical details around API payloads and error handling
- Includes validation and error handling requirements

Areas for Improvement:
- Could benefit from a 'Context' section explaining the overall workflow and how this fits in
- 'Out of Scope' section would help clarify boundaries
- No mention of non-functional requirements like performance expectations
- Could provide more details on expected error scenarios and how to handle them
- Missing information about test coverage expectations

The ticket seems implementation-ready but would benefit from additional context and clarification of non-functional requirements. Given the complexity of integrating with APIs and handling configurations, a medium-high estimate seems appropriate based on reference tickets.

name: Tech Lead - Give feedback on jira ticket

parameters.jsonExample:
{
  "Jira Ticket Type": "Story",  
  "Jira Ticket Summary": "TestRail Setup: Configure TestRail as our test management tool",
    "Jira Ticket Description": "## User Story

As a quality engineer, I want TestRail configured and integrated with our development workflow, so our team can efficiently manage and execute test cases.

## Context

* TestRail is a widely-used test management tool that integrates well with Jira
* It provides features for test case management, test execution tracking, and reporting
* Having a dedicated test management tool will help standardize our QA processes

## Acceptance Criteria

* TestRail instance is set up and configured
* TestRail is integrated with our Jira instance
* Test suites are created to match our key product areas
* Sample test cases are created to validate the setup
* Documentation is created explaining how to:
  - Create and manage test cases
  - Execute test runs
  - View and generate reports
  - Link test cases to Jira issues
* Team members are provided access with appropriate roles
* Knowledge transfer session is conducted for the team

## Resources

* TestRail documentation: https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/
* Jira integration guide: https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/integrate/jira/",
    "Jira Ticket Labels": [
      "Quality_Assurance",
      "Groomed",
      "Confidence_High",
      "V0.0.1"
    ],
    "Jira Ticket Fix Version": "V0.0.1",
    "Jira Ticket Epic Id": "WEN-417"
  }

workflowId.cachedResultName: Tech Lead - Get Technical Standards Docs

json.Jira Ticket Summary: TestRail Setup: Configure TestRail as our test management tool
json.Jira Ticket Description:
## User Story

As a quality engineer, I want TestRail configured and integrated with our development workflow, so our team can efficiently manage and execute test cases.

## Context

* TestRail is a widely-used test management tool that integrates well with Jira
* It provides features for test case management, test execution tracking, and reporting
* Having a dedicated test management tool will help standardize our QA processes

## Acceptance Criteria

* TestRail instance is set up and configured
* TestRail is integrated with our Jira instance
* Test suites are created to match our key product areas
* Sample test cases are created to validate the setup
* Documentation is created explaining how to:
  - Create and manage test cases
  - Execute test runs
  - View and generate reports
  - Link test cases to Jira issues
* Team members are provided access with appropriate roles
* Knowledge transfer session is conducted for the team

## Resources

* TestRail documentation: https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/
* Jira integration guide: https://www.gurock.com/testrail/docs/integrate/jira/

json.Feedback:
The ticket WEN-472 'Vendor Script: Implement scheduler config check via API integration' is fairly well structured but has some areas for improvement:

Strengths:
- Clear user story that describes the goal
- Acceptance criteria breaks down the key requirements
- Good technical details around API payloads and error handling
- Includes validation and error handling requirements

Areas for Improvement:
- Could benefit from a 'Context' section explaining the overall workflow and how this fits in
- 'Out of Scope' section would help clarify boundaries
- No mention of non-functional requirements like performance expectations
- Could provide more details on expected error scenarios and how to handle them
- Missing information about test coverage expectations

The ticket seems implementation-ready but would benefit from additional context and clarification of non-functional requirements. Given the complexity of integrating with APIs and handling configurations, a medium-high estimate seems appropriate based on reference tickets.

options.systemMessage:
=You are a highly experienced product manager with deep experience in building SaaS products, adhering to Agile best practices, and crafting comprehensive, clear, and highly effective Jira stories for your engineering teams. Your job is to create a Jira ticket given the issue request below work with your TechLead to refine it until it is high enough quality to meet the standard "Definition of Ready". Use the below steps to create and refine the desired jira ticket:

1. Always start by generating an initial Jira ticket by using the `Get_Initial_Jira_Ticket` tool.

2. Once an initial jira ticket has been generated in Step 1, provide it to your tech lead for a score, detailed feedback, and a time estimate for the jira ticket by using the `Get_Tech_Lead_Feedback` tool.

3. If the score is below 0.8, use the feedback from step 2 to refine the post, by calling the `Refine_Jira_Ticket` tool.

5. The final output should be the polished final Jira Ticket following this JSON format:

---
{
  "issueType": "<Story, Bug, Task, Epic>",
  "summary": "<Feature Name>: <Concise summary for given the feature prompt>",
  "description": "h2. User Story\n\nAs a <persona type>, I want <something to exist, be done, etc>, so <I or someone related to me can benefit in XYZ way>.\n\nh2. Context\n\n* <Some contextual information 1>\n* <Some contextual information 2>\n* <Some contextual information 3>\n\nh2. Acceptance Criteria\n\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 1 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 2 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 3 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n\nh2. Resources\n\n* <Any relevant resource 1>\n* <Any relevant resource 2>",
  "labels": ["<new or pre-existing label 1 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')", "<new or pre-existing label 2 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')"],
  "fixVersion": "<Either our current fixVersion, 'V0.0.1', or our future next release, 'V0.0.2'>",
  "epicId": "<If a pre-existing suitable epic exists from our pre-existing Jira Stories, then use its id here>",
  "estimatedTime": 7200
}
---

parameters.name: Get_Initial_Jira_Ticket
parameters.description: Call this tool to generate a jira ticket object given an issue request or feedback.

parameters.name: Get_Tech_Lead_Feedback
parameters.description: Call this tool to get feedback on a jira ticket from your technical lead and principal engineer

value.Jira Ticket Type: ={{ /*n8n-auto-generated-fromAI-override*/ $fromAI('Jira_Ticket_Type', "The Jira Ticket Type from calling the `Get_Initial_Jira_Ticket` in the form of a `String`", 'string') }}

value.Tech Lead Feedback: ={{ /*n8n-auto-generated-fromAI-override*/ $fromAI('Tech_Lead_Feedback', "The score, feedback, and estimatedTime (entire JSON response) from calling `Get_Tech_Lead_Feedback`", 'string') }}

name: Tech Lead - Get Technical Architecture Docs
Tech Lead - Get Technical Standards Docs

parameters.text:
=You are a highly experienced product manager with deep experience in building SaaS products, adhering to Agile best practices, and crafting comprehensive, clear, and highly effective Jira stories for your engineering teams.

## Objective
Create a well structured Jira story that aligns with product management, Agile, and Jira best practices given the `Product Overview` our `Issue Request`, as well as our `Current Jira Stories` below. Use Jira's wikimarkup syntax for the description field. Format the output as a JSON object with the following fields:

---
JSON output format:
{
  "issueType": "<Story, Bug, Task, Epic>",
  "summary": "<Feature Name>: <Concise summary for given the feature prompt>",
  "description": "h2. User Story\n\nAs a <persona type>, I want <something to exist, be done, etc>, so <I or someone related to me can benefit in XYZ way>.\n\nh2. Context\n\n* <Some contextual information 1>\n* <Some contextual information 2>\n* <Some contextual information 3>\n\nh2. Acceptance Criteria\n\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 1 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 2 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n* <Acceptance criteria bullet point 3 (functional and/or non-functional requirement)>\n\nh2. Resources\n\n* <Any relevant resource 1>\n* <Any relevant resource 2>",
 "labels": ["<new or pre-existing label 1 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')", "<new or pre-existing label 2 (eg. 'API', 'UI', 'QA', 'Storybook', 'V0.0.1', 'Future_Release')"],
  "fixVersion": "<Either our current fixVersion, 'V0.0.1', or our future next release, 'V0.0.2'>",
  "epicId": "<If a pre-existing suitable epic exists from our pre-existing Jira Stories, then use its id here>"
}
---

## Product Overview: 

{{ $('Get Project Overview').item.json.content }}

---

## Issue Request:

{{ $('When Executed by Another Workflow').item.json.query }}

---

## References

### Current Jira Stories:
{{ $json['Jira Ticket'] }}

json.query: Add a story for setting up TestRail as our test management tool of choice
